metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Tuberculosis, COVID-19 and migrants: preliminary analysis of deaths occurring in 69 patients from two cohorts

body_text.text: s World Health Organization Regional office for Europe, Copenhagen, Denmark 53 Little is known about the relationship between the COVID-19 and tuberculosis (TB). The aim of 54 this study is to describe a group of patients who died with TB (active disease or sequelae) and 55 COVID-19 in two cohorts. 56 Data from 49 consecutive cases in 8 countries (cohort A) and 20 hospitalized patients with TB and 57 COVID-19 (cohort B) were analysed and patients who died were described. Demographic and 58 clinical variables were retrospectively collected, including co-morbidities and risk factors for TB 59 and COVID-19 mortality. 60 Overall, 8 out of 69 (11.6%) patients died, 7 from cohort A (14.3%) and one from cohort B (5%). 61 Out of 69 patients 43 were migrants, 26/49 (53.1%) in cohort A and 17/20 (85.0%) in cohort B. The study findings show that: 1) mortality is likely to occur in elderly patients with co-morbidities; 67 2) TB might not be a major determinant of mortality and 3) migrants had lower mortality, probably 68 because of their younger age and lower number of co-morbidities. However, in settings where 69 advanced forms of TB frequently occur and are caused by drug-resistant strains of M. tuberculosis, 70 higher mortality rates can be expected in young individuals.

The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 (severe acute respiratory syndrome 76 coronavirus 2) is causing a debate on preventive, diagnostic, and therapeutic strategies among 77 scientists, clinicians, and public health experts [1] [2] [3] . 78 The current scientific evidence suggests that individuals with the disease are infectious, SARS-79 CoV-2 rapidly spreads within the community because of the lack of herd immunity 4,5 , it has high 80 case-fatality rate among elderly and patients with co-morbidities and can stretch unprepared 81 healthcare systems causing rapid collapse of intensive care units (ICU) 1-3,6 .

Patients with COVID-19 may complain of cough, fever, tiredness, dyspnoea, and other signs and The aim of this study is to describe for the first time a group of patients who died with TB (active 89 disease or sequelae) and COVID-19 in the cohorts A and B. All consecutive cases with a diagnosis of TB (at any time in the past, so as to include patients with 101 TB sequelae, which may be a risk factor for mortality) and COVID-19 from cohorts A and B were 102 included.

J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f TB patients were microbiologically confirmed (Table 1) , whereas SARS-CoV-2 infection was 106 confirmed by molecular biology. The first COVID-19 diagnosis was made on March 12 th , 2020; 107 data were updated as of May 5 th , 2020.
Continuous variables, if not otherwise specified, are presented as medians (IQR-Interquartile 109 ranges). Categorical variables were described with absolute and relative (percentage) frequencies.
Chi-squared and Fisher exact tests were used to compare qualitative variables when appropriate. A 111 two-tailed p-value less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

The MuLBSTA (multilobular infiltration, hypo-lymphocytosis, bacterial coinfection, smoking 113 history, hypertension, and age) clinical score used to predict 90-day mortality due to viral To the best of our knowledge this is the first report of patients dying with TB and COVID-19, 150 including 69 patients from the two largest cohorts of co-infected patients available so far.

Although the case-fatality rate was rather high (overall 10.6%, but 14.3% in the first cohort) and 152 still preliminary (it can increase over time within both cohorts), the results seem consistent with 153 those observed in other cohorts of COVID-19 patients 1-3 . In general, all patients (except one) were 154 aged >65 years, and were affected by >2 co-morbidities.
In all cases COVID-19 contributed to worsen the prognosis of TB patients and/or to cause death.

The MuLBSTA score has been developed for viral pneumonia 11 and has similar inputs to risk 162 factors for mortality seen in the initial COVID-19 patient cohorts in China 12 . Age has a much 163 stronger odds ratio for increasing mortality in COVID-19 patients than in other viral pneumonia 164 patients. A score higher than 12 points is considered high risk (bacterial coinfection detected by 165 sputum or culture -as for concomitant active TB counts 4 points.) In our patients it does not seem to 166 predict mortality well: the median value is 10 and only 2 patients scored values higher than 12.
TB and COVID-19 seem to absorb relevant human and economic resources, although the relatively 168 small size of the cohort prevents drawing specific conclusions.
The main limitation of this preliminary study is that the cohort, although likely to report the vast

The study findings show that: 1) mortality is likely to occur in elderly patients with co-morbidities; 173 2) TB might not be a major determinant of mortality and 3) migrants had lower mortality, probably 174 because of their younger age and lower number of co-morbidities. However, in settings where 175 advanced forms of TB frequently occur and are caused by drug-resistant strains of M. tuberculosis, 176 higher mortality rates can be expected in young individuals.

body_text.text: However, as the study will continue prospectively with the inclusion of GTN countries where TB 178 and COVID-19 patients have not been diagnosed until now, we wish to invite all interested 179 clinicians and programmes to contact us and participate in the study. The following clinicians participate in the project:

FIGREF1.text: to those of tuberculosis (TB) and of other respiratory infections 7 . 84 Little is known about the relationship between the COVID-19 and TB. Data from 49 cases (cohort 85 A) reported elsewhere 7 show that COVID-19 can occur before, simultaneously, or after the 86 diagnosis of TB. Furthermore, additional information from 20 hospitalized patients with TB and 87 COVID-19 (cohort B) is available (Stochino C. et al, unpublished data).

FIGREF3.text: both cohorts were combined to assess the mortality. Cohort A included 49 patients with TB 93 and COVID-19 from 26 centres in Belgium, Brazil, France, Italy, Russia, Singapore, Spain, and 94 Switzerland 7 , whereas cohort B included 20 cases admitted to a single reference hospital located in 95 Northern Italy. 96 Both cohorts belong to nested studies of the Global Tuberculosis Network (GTN) large 97 observational project monitoring adverse reactions to anti-TB drugs for which the coordinating 98 centre in Tradate (Italy) has the ethical approval (and other participating centres according to the 99 respective national regulations) 7-9 .

FIGREF6.text: All but one (patient 7) were males, with a median age of 70 (range 45-82) years, and had TB 120 diagnosed before COVID-19; only patient 8 had almost simultaneous diagnosis of COVID-19 and 121 TB. They showed from 2 to 5 co-morbidities, for two patients being cancer (haematological and 122 prostatic, and for patient 7 underlying cancer could not be excluded, although the rapid decline and123 death prevented the possibility of diagnosing it); one patient was co-infected with HIV and 124 HBV/HDV (chronic hepatitis B virus and hepatitis delta virus). 125 Out of 69 patients 43 were migrants, 26/49 (53.1%) in cohort A and 17/20 (85.0%) in cohort B. 126 Migrants were younger than natives: in cohort A the median (IQR) age was 40 (27-49) VS. 66 (46-127 70) years, whereas in cohort B 37 (27-46) VS. 48 (47-60) years.128Overall, migrants had a lower mortality rate than natives (1/43, 2.3% versus 7/26, 26.9%; p-value: 129 0.002).

FIGREF7.text: Migrants had fewer co-morbidities than natives; in particular, 23/43 (53.5%) migrants had no co-131 morbidities versus 5/26 (19.2%) natives (p-value: 0.005). 132 Among the patients who died, 3 were vaccinated with Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG); 4 were 133 infected by pan-susceptible Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains and one by Mycobacterium bovis, 134 which is intrinsically resistant to pyrazinamide. Except patient 3 who had TB diagnosed in 2016 and 135 was declared cured (affected by post-treatment sequelae) and patient 8 (simultaneous diagnosis of 136 COVID-10 and TB), the remaining patients had COVID-19 diagnosed between 7 and 75 days 137 (median: 22.5 days) after the TB diagnosis. In 6/7 patients SARS-CoV-2 infection was nosocomial.Table 1and 2). TB was treated using first-line drugs; five patients were treated with 141 hydroxychloroquine for COVID-19. Four patients needed oxygen therapy through face mask and 142 one underwent non-invasive ventilation. Death occurred after a median of 9 (range 6-14) days after 143 COVID-19 diagnosis. COVID-19 was considered relevant in either causing death or accelerating its 144 occurrence. Median (range) hospital stay was 27.

FIGREF8.text: In the majority of patients who died, SARS-CoV-2 infection was nosocomial during early phases of157 the outbreak in Northern Italy and Spain. This highlights the importance of implementing strict 158 infection control interventions for all hospitalized patients (and, particularly, for those at higher risk, 159 e.g. elderly and patients with co-morbidities including TB), taking into account the risk of viral 160 transmission from other patients, visitors, and healthcare workers 4,5 .

FIGREF9.text: 170 majority of cases with TB and COVID-19 in the countries surveyed, cannot be considered 171 representative either of the European nor of the global situation.
